Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Maintain a friendly and approachable demeanor
Situation2: The acquaintance encounters a person who is visibly upset and crying about a recent event.
Story: I was at a friend’s birthday party when I noticed my younger brother standing awkwardly by the snack table, glancing at me every so often. I’d invited him because I wanted us to spend more time together, to show him he was welcome in my world. But as the night went on, I found myself drifting toward my own group of friends, trying to keep conversations light and easy. That’s when I saw an acquaintance, Sarah, sitting alone on the porch, her shoulders shaking as she wiped away tears. I knew I should go over, offer a kind word, maybe just sit with her for a while—after all, that’s what a decent person would do. But then I caught my brother’s eye again; he looked lost, out of place, and I remembered my promise to include him, to make him feel like he belonged. I felt torn, the weight of both expectations pressing down on me, unsure which role I should step into first.
